article_title: Will the blizzard prompt an open enrollment extension?
article_text:
Will the blizzard prompt an open enrollment extension?

D.C. IS SNOWED OUT — Or maybe it’s snowed in? Either way, the House is out for the whole week, citing the "severity" of winter storm Jonas and the travel challenges. Federal agencies also are closed today.

— Will ACA open enrollment be extended? The current period is scheduled to run through Jan. 31. But given the weather snarling the East Coast — plus the somewhat lackluster enrollment numbers in recent weeks — it wouldn't be a surprise to see HHS and state agencies push the deadline back, at least in blizzard-affected areas. They've done it in past years.

Story Continued Below

WELCOME TO MONDAY — where Washington is continuing to thaw out from one of its biggest snowstorms in history. But how much snow did Washington get, anyway? The official numbers are being clouded by a minor scandal: The team of weather observers at Reagan National Airport messed up and lost their device. "It was buried by the very snow it was supposed to measure," the Washington Post ruefully noted. As a result, the super-storm may not take its rightful place in weather history.

Mismanaged data collection — an idea that health wonks and politicos can relate to. Email me at ddiamond@politico.com or find me on Twitter at @ddiamond.

TED CRUZ IS INSURED AFTER ALL — The senator on Thursday told voters in New Hampshire that he was uninsured, after Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Texas canceled his PPO policy in December. But it turns out Blue Cross actually re-enrolled Cruz into a narrow-network HMO, his presidential campaign explained on Friday night. "Sen. Cruz believed the family was uninsured and asked the broker to pull quotes immediately for a new policy," a Cruz spokesperson said. "The Cruz family is currently covered by a Blue Cross HMO."

OBAMA ON AMERICA'S UNINSURED PROBLEMS: 'WE'VE CHANGED THAT' — The president's weekly address on Saturday focused on the Affordable Care Act's ripple effects, which he says have led to a healthier population and more stable economy. "When I took office seven years ago this week, more than 15 percent of Americans went without health insurance," Obama said. "We’ve changed that."

In his address, Obama listed some of the law's benefits, including the requirement that insurers cover patients with pre-existing conditions. The president also stressed that — for the first time — more than 90 percent of Americans have health coverage. Here’s his full statement:http://1.usa.gov/23kEI0O

CANDIDATES ON HEALTH CARE — There was a fair amount of health care talk on the Sunday shows, with both leading Democratic candidates elaborating on their planned reforms.

— Clinton pushes coverage expansion, pharma reform. Appearing on "Meet the Press," Hillary Clinton reiterated her goal is to get Americans "to 100 percent" health coverage and promised to "roll out what I intend to do to get there."

She also stressed that pharmaceutical reforms would be among her top priorities as president, including lowering the cost of medication. "I'm going to use whatever tools I can to get us lower prices [and] cap those prescription drug companies," she told host Chuck Todd.

— Sanders sticks to Medicare-for-all talking points. On "Face the Nation," host John Dickerson pressed Bernie Sanders on his proposal to create a Medicare-for-all health insurance system, posing a question that's been mostly overlooked: Would Sanders' plan lead to long wait times?

"One of the criticisms of a national health care plan in other places is, maybe people can be covered, but the waiting times to get to actually see a doctor can be long and excruciatingly long," Dickerson said. "What is your solution?"

Sanders didn't answer directly, but stressed that the United States is among the only major countries without universal coverage. "A Medicare-for-all single-payer system can guarantee quality health care to all of our people, and at the same time save middle-class families thousands of dollars a year," Sanders said.

WHERE THEY STAND ON ABORTION POLICY — The candidates also are ramping up their language on abortion, Jennifer Haberkorn reports for Pro — and increasingly taking vocal stances. "On the Republican side, all of the candidates oppose abortion and back legislation to ban it after 20 weeks of pregnancy," she writes. Meanwhile, the Democratic candidates strongly support abortion rights; Clinton has called to strike down the ban on federal funding of abortion, and Sanders on Friday argued to do the same.

As Jen writes, one reason why the stakes are so high is that the next president could appoint more than one Supreme Court justice, which could potentially undo the Roe v. Wade decision legalizing abortion. Her story:

— One remarkable stat on our aging court: Jen's story reminds me of an incredible data point she shared last week: By Election Day, at least three Supreme Court justices will be 80 years old and a fourth will be 78 years old.

** A message from PhRMA: Coverage does not necessarily mean access to care. More medicines are being excluded from coverage, deductibles and copays are going up and insurance companies are increasingly imposing other barriers to access. Know the 5 reasons you may not get the medicine you need. Learn more at AccessBetterCoverage.org - http://onphr.ma/23fm1LW **

MARKEY PUTS HOLD ON CALIFF — Sen. Ed Markey has put a hold on Robert Califf's nomination to lead the FDA because of the agency's approval of OxyContin for children and its overall practices for reviewing opioid painkillers, Sarah Karlin reports for Pro.

— Of course, no vote had been scheduled yet. Sen. Lisa Murkowski is already blocking a floor vote on Califf over the agency's decision not to require labeling of genetically engineering salmon, and Sen. Bernie Sanders also may hold up Califf's nomination because of his ties to the drug industry.

ZIKA VIRUS CONTINUES TO SPREAD — Three patients in New York State have tested positive for the virus, which is transmitted by mosquito and currently spreading across the Caribbean and Latin America. (All three patients recently returned from overseas.)

— Why Zika is a concern: The virus's symptoms, which are relatively mild and flu-like, appear to be linked with brain damage in infants. El Salvador health officials are urging women not to get pregnant until 2018, and other Latin American countries have similar measures. There is no medication or vaccine to treat the virus.

IN THE STATES: Lawmakers have again rejected Republican Gov. Matt Mead's proposal to expand the state’s Medicaid program, which would have extended health coverage to nearly 20,000 low-income adults. And it's not likely to move ahead on a different path this year. In Colorado, advocates are holding a community forum on ColoradoCare, a single-payer plan that will be on the November ballot. More from State Week.

GOP LAWMAKER: MEDICAID EXPANSION IS 'INEVITABLE' IN GEORGIA — Jim Galloway at the Atlanta Journal-Constitution flagged this: A local Republican lawmaker thinks Obamacare's Medicaid expansion is "inevitable." "I believe we will expand Medicaid," State Sen. Fran Millar told local TV last week. "We want to do it so we have more control of it," he added, pointing to the Arkansas model. You may recall the state's chamber of commerce is in the midst of a nine-month study on health care access that could tee up a Medicaid debate in 2017.

WSJ: THERANOS WOES COULD BUMP LAB FROM MEDICARE PARTICIPATION — CMS inspectors have found "serious deficiencies" at the lab-testing company and will release a formal report soon, the Wall Street Journal reports. "Failing to fix the problems could put the Theranos lab at risk of suspension from the Medicare program," the Journal adds.

Of course, many providers run afoul of Medicare inspections — and most of those issues get successfully resolved — so until we get more details, it's hard to know just how bad Theranos' latest problems actually are.

CONGRATS TO NEW WINSTON FELLOWS — Olivia Pham, who currently attends the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill's public health program, and Kripa Sreepada, who attends Cornell University's Sloan Program in health administration, have been selected as the 2016-2017 Winston Health Policy Fellows a year long post-graduate experience in Washington, D.C. Current fellows Adrianna McIntyre and Lydia Orth were placed in Nancy Pelosi’s office and the Democratic Health Subcommittee for Ways and Means, respectively.

AVALERE ON HOW MEDICARE ADVANTAGE UNDERPAYS PLANS — On Friday, I reported that Avalere Health would release a new report that concluded Medicare Advantage's underpaying plans for chronically ill patients. The study's now posted, and here's a link.

WHAT WE'RE READING

At Business Insider, Lydia Ramsey quizzed experts about which idea will disrupt the health care industry in 2016. http://read.bi/1WINIbo

More companies are using sticks, not just carrots, to get employees into wellness programs, the New York Times reports. http://nyti.ms/1KyVqh9

Massachusetts is luring GE to set up its headquarters in the state, and officials have earmarked $5 million for GE to establish an "innovation center" focused on life sciences and digital health. The Boston Globe: http://bit.ly/1SdOigx

Working with Atul Gawande and the Harvard School of Public Health, South Carolina hospitals are piloting a statewide project to use surgical checklists, Modern Healthcare reports. http://bit.ly/1QnojBm

Clayton McWhorter, the former CEO of HCA and a prominent health care businessman, passed away this weekend. He was 82 years old. The Tennessean story: http://tnne.ws/1K5AnIf

** A message from PhRMA: The medicine you need may not be covered by your health insurance plan or plans may require very high cost sharing. Insurers are increasingly making it hard to get the treatments you need to live a longer, healthier life by increasing deductibles and copays and creating other barriers to access. Here are 5 ways insurers may prevent you from accessing the medicine you need: (1) Prior authorization (2) Step therapy (3) Non-medical switching (4) High out-of-pocket costs (5) Not covered at all. When you’re choosing coverage be sure to look carefully at how — and if — the medicines you and your family need are covered. Learn more about these terms at AccessBetterCoverage.org - http://onphr.ma/23fm1LW **

** A message from National Community Pharmacists Association (NCPA): While approximately 80 percent of prescription drugs dispensed are generic drugs, the reimbursement system for these medications is largely unregulated and a mystery to pharmacists and patients. The lack of transparency also raises questions as to whether drug plan middlemen, pharmacy benefit manager (PBM) corporations, are overpaid by Medicare and other federal health programs. Moreover, when generic drug prices spike, PBM corporations are slow to update reimbursement rates, leaving community pharmacies with payments that don’t cover costs and unsustainable financial losses. H.R. 244 would increase transparency and facilitate timely payment updates. Learn more at www.ncpanet.org/pharmacyaccess. **
